sn1.46:1.1: The nymphs (accharā, “aquatics”, perhaps originally cloud-deities) were known from Vedic times as beautiful dancers and musicians often romantically entwined with the gandhabba.
sn1.46:1.2: As horrifying as nymphs are seductive, the flesh-eating pisāca (Sanskrit piśāca) arises in troops under cover of night and slips through the air wreaking havoc.
sn1.46:1.3: Delusion contains both desire and aversion.
sn1.46:2.1: This Sutta contrasts the “direct” way with the “deluding” (mohana) way. This recalls the notion that the teaching shows the way to those who are lost (mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, SN 7.1:9.3). This echoes the common description of the Saṅgha as practicing the way that is “direct”, suggesting that they are proceeding directly along a known route (SN 11.3:11.2).
sn1.46:2.4: Normally dhammacakka, the “wheel of the teaching”, is singular, this being a unique plural. The commentary explains as mental and physical energy.
